comments.body:
Hmm, I think that this needs to be specified something like this:

```typescript
capture(id: string, response?: IResponseFn<charges.ICharge>): Promise<charges.ICharge>;
capture(id: string, data: charges.IChargeCaptureOptions, response?: IResponseFn<charges.ICharge>): Promise<charges.ICharge>;
capture(id: string, options: HeaderOptions, response?: IResponseFn<charges.ICharge>): Promise<charges.ICharge>;
capture(id: string, data: charges.IChargeCaptureOptions, options: HeaderOptions, response?: IResponseFn<charges.ICharge>): Promise<charges.ICharge>;
```

since all of this calls are okay:

```js
capture(id)
capture(id, (err) => {})
capture(id, data)
capture(id, data, (err) => {})
capture(id, options)
capture(id, options, (err) => {})
capture(id, data, options)
capture(id, data, options, (err) => {})
```

note that the Stripe client differs `data` from `options` by looking at the keys in the object

any thoughts @lauvigne, @DanielRosenwasser?
Yes you are right, it's better!

since this is a major version upgrade, please take a copy of the old definition files, and put it under a new folder `v4`. see https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped#i-want-to-update-a-package-to-a-new-major-version
Have you got any documentation for where you got these properties? I can't seem to find any application object documented on the Stripe API docs.
I see why you've done this though, as the `application` property is `Expandable`
Yes. Actually I figured this out from the official .Net API code. Though there are no docs about this anywhere else and I wasn't able to actually test it.
The field names don't need quotes around them.
Why have these been made optional?
Well, this is primarily a data model object. For some reason when I actually use the library I've noticed the quite often I don't really have these functions available. This is why I did that.
This type is copy paste from above, consider moving this into a type.
It's optional here but required above. Should I use Partial? I couldn't see it in use anywhere else in the file.
No, you can use `type UsageType = "metered" | "licensed"` instead and re-use that type.
And again, this applies to all string unions you added.
`type` should never be prefixed with `I` iirc.
The existing code uses this naming pattern all over. I think it would be better to remove the lint exception and fix all names in a separate PR.

https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/object#customer_bank_account_object-account_holder_type

Stripe will set this to `null` in responses if the value is not set.
The docs mention credit or debit cards, but bank accounts (among others) are also valid: https://stripe.com/docs/api/charges/create#create_charge-source
Stripe sets this to `null` if the value is not set.
Stripe does not always return this value. There is no documentation on what this value is at https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/object#customer_bank_account_object-account
This does not appear to be present in most IBankAccount responses, and it is not mentioned in the docs at https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/object

`bank_account` is the proper name of the object, and it is what stripe currently returns: https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/object#customer_bank_account_object-object

The only reference I could find to `customer_bank_account` is an old IRC chat that mentions it was a documentation mistake: https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:RXkeQmg0xLUJ:https://botbot.me/freenode/stripe/2016-04-14/%3Fpage%3D5+&cd=3&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us
Stripe returns `null` if this value is not set.

These are the only valid values: https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/object#customer_bank_account_object-account_holder_type

Stripe will return `null` if the value is not set.

This field is mentioned in the stripe API docs without explanation. In practice, it does appear to be the customer ID.
https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/object#customer_bank_account_object-customer
Fixed "errored" value: https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/object#customer_bank_account_object-status
There was previously no type for the `verirfySource` parameters: https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/verify
Values: https://stripe.com/docs/api/cards/object#card_object-address_line1_check
This will be `null` if no zip code was provided.
Values: https://stripe.com/docs/api/cards/object#card_object-address_zip_check
This previously did not include the proper types for the verification amounts: https://stripe.com/docs/api/customer_bank_accounts/verify
I think this type is complex enough to extract it.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +724,728 @@             * Only returns transactions of the given type.
             */
            type?: "charge" | "refund" | "adjustment" | "application_fee" |
                "application_fee_refund" | "transfer" | "payment" | "payout" | "payout_failure" | "stripe_fee" | "network_cost";

comments.body: Just wanted to double check on the intent here. Either the property is not set (undefined), or it is set with a valid value. Is it intentional that the value can be set to be `null`? From the docs, it seems like the if it is set, it will be a single plan (which I would assume is not going to be `null`).

Currently the API does return `null`.  However, the docs say it isn't set, so I guess I'm leaving it open to both here.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/327833/51873712-1b3f6100-2313-11e9-9567-0733c0d44ea5.png)
It looks like `quantity`, `tax_percent`, `trial_end`, and `trial_start` should also be marked as nullable based on the api response I'm seeing above, currently the typing here requires a `number`

the nullable types are a bit of a mess at the moment, the Stripe documentation isn't the best unfortunately 😞 I got a response from an employee of Stripe to use their OpenAPI spec as the "golden standard"

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/issues/27656
Nit: The indents are all wrong, please use 4 spaces instead of tabs.

Could you kindly remove me as a contributor in this PR?
Getting waaay too many emails from this.
This appears to have been a copy/paste error.

This will be null if the PaymentIntent is used with a PaymentMethod instead of a source.
When would this and the next one be null? If using sources instead of payment methods?
Yes, that's exactly right.
nit: use double quotes.

I was trying to follow the style within the `paymentIntent` namespace, which appears to be single quotes, but I didn't even manage that unfortunately (like at line 4508). The file uses a mix of single and double quotes. Do you think it'd be a good idea to add a lint rule to standardize it?
Ah, gotcha - not blocking. I'm not too familiar with how linting works in this repo so don't feel too strongly, but in any case that would be a task for a separate PR.
https://stripe.com/docs/api/payment_methods/object#payment_method_object-card

😳 https://github.com/stripe/stripe-node/blob/master/lib/resources.js#L13

I'm not familiar with this library, but the docs don't seem to say that this is optional: https://stripe.com/docs/api/subscription_items/object#subscription_item_object-quantity

Am I missing something obvious?

It isn't entirely obvious from the docs, but if your subscription uses [metered billing](https://stripe.com/docs/billing/subscriptions/quantities) (see also [`billing_scheme`](https://stripe.com/docs/api/plans/object#plan_object-billing_scheme)) then `quantity` isn't returned at all.

I believe all of these CRUDL functions should have an overload that accepts a `HeaderOptions` param before the `IResponseFn`.
Good catch, I didn't think to look at the other CRUDL types and only looked at the documentation where this isn't explicitly mentioned on each function. I _think_ it should be correct now
